ResearchProjectDef.label: gnome knowledge
ResearchProjectDef.description: Learn the basic culture and cuisine of the Gnome peoples.
ResearchProjectDef.discoveredLetterTitle: Gnome Knowledge Unlocked: How to Use Gnome Root Poppies
ResearchProjectDef.discoveredLetterText:
Congratulations on researching Gnome Knowledge! You have begun your first foray into the amazing culinary and aristic endeavors of this ancient, gnoble subspecies of man. You will need a Grinder or other grinding pestle for many of these recipes, so make sure you install one! 
 
 Of particular interest to any chef is the Gnome Root poppy. When harvested, Gnome Root poppies can be ground at a Grinder or Gnome Table. 
 Grinding Gnome Root poppies yields special Plant Matter called "gnome flour", which is used in baking and the gourmet Gnome Cuisine for which Gnome culture is famous. Gnome flour is not traditionally used for general cooking purposes, but this is possible by reassigning it as "gnome meal". 
 
 If you wish for your gnome flour to be used identically to all other plant-based ingredients (and vice-versa, to reserve it back), use the "Designate Gnome Flour" series of "recipes", which are found at any place used to grind Gnome Root poppies.

ResearchProjectDef.label: pizza cooking
ResearchProjectDef.description:
Make it pizza time, all the time. 
 
 The term "pizza" has existed for approximately four thousand four hundred years and is actually a German word, from "pizzo", generated by the Gothics and Lombards that controlled northern Italy in the time period. Though its literal translation is "bite", its actual and contexual use roughly translated to "mouthful of bread" or "bite [a] piece of bread", and was their answer to the Italian word "pita (bread)". 
 
 Old Earth historians have maintained that what is now called pizza was invented over three thousand six hundred years ago. Interestingly, Old Earth Italians consumed pizza with a knife and fork, not by hand.
